SCIENTIF AFFAIRS
04/11/95 TUE 13:05 FAX 804 274 3055 - REGULATORY TOXICOLOGY AND PHARMACOLOGY 21, 180-183 (1998)
Ischemic Heart Disease and Spousal Smoking In the National Mortality Followback Survey1
MAXWELL W. LAYARD Layard Aurociates, Alameda, California 94802
Roccivad June 25, 1994
Date on never-smoking decedents from the 1986 Na- tional Mortality Followback Survey were used to por- form a casa-control analysis of lechemid heart dicenne In relation to spousal cigarette smoking, The cape groupe consisted of 475 men and 914 women who died from heart disease. Controls consisted of 998 men and 1930 women who died from other causes. In this study there was no association between spousal smoking and fachomle heart disease in either max (males, odds ratio 0.97: fomalos, odds ratio - 0.99). The results of this study are In striking diaagreement with rjak alevations roportod in several previous studies of spousal smoking and heart disease. # 1605 Asademle Prom, Int.
INTRODUCTION
Several epidemiologic studies have reported associ- ations between lachemie heart disease mortality in never-smokers and exposure to environmental to. bacco smoke (ETS) from spousal smoking (Hitayams, 1984; Garland et al., 1985; Lae et al., 1986; Martin et aL .. 1986; Svendsen et al, 1987; Butler, 1988; Helsing et al, 1988; Palmer et al., 1988; He, 1989; Hole et al., 1989; Jackson, 1989; Humble et al., 1990; Dobson at al, 1991; LaVecchia et al., 1993; He et al., 1994). Da- spite the high rate of heart disease death among never- smokers, most of those studies have included rola- tively few cases; only three studies (Hirayama, 1984; Helsing et al., 1988; Dobson et al., 1991) included sub- stantially more than 100 cases. Although some review panela concluded that there was insufficient evidence to infer that ETS exposure Increases the risk of heart disease (National Research Council, 1986; U.S. Surgeon General, 1986), other reviewers have drawn
I This work was kupparsed in part by the Cantor for Indoor Air Ra- search. The views expressed topresent the personal opinions of the auchor und are not noconarily those of the Conter for Indoor Air Re- search.
such an inference (Walls, 1988; Glantz and Parmisy, 1991; Steenland, 1992; Taylor et al., 1992).
The National Mortality Followback Survey (NMFS), which was based on a probability sample of adult deaths in the United States in 1986, offered the opportunity to perform a cast-control analysis of ischemie heart dia- case and spousal smoking that includes more never- smoking cases than any previously published study. This paper reports the results of that case-control study.
MATERIALS AND METHODS
The National Mortality Followback Survey was conducted in 1986 by the U.S. National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) (NCHS, 1988; Seeman et al, 1989). The survey was based on a national proba. bility sample of about 1% of all deaths in 1986 of U.S. residents aged 25 years or older. This sample wor drawn from the Current Mortality Sample (CMS), & 10% sample of death certificates that NCHS receiver from state authorities approximately 2 months after the deaths occur. The NMES sample included data from 49 states and the District of Columbia; deaths from Oregon were not included because of respondent consent requirements.
-
Of the 18,793 death certificates in the NMFS som- ple, about 2500 were selected with certainty from the CMS for certain causes of death and population sub- groups. These included all deaths due to ischemic heart disease (International Classification of Dis- sases, Revision 9, codes 410-414) for males aged 25-44 years and for females aged 25-54 years. In addition. some population groups were oversampled. For exam- ple, black decedents were oversampled 2.9 times and those under 55 years of age wers oversampled 3.1 times.
Next of kin of decedents in the NMFS sample were asked to complete a questionnaire that included ques- tions on demographic characteristics, dietary pat- terna, cigarette smoking (personal and spousal), alco- hal consumption, education, income, and history of :selected: 009
